As Democrats take control of the House, it is imperative that we work to address the systemic racial biases within American housing markets. I look forward to working with members from both sides of the aisle to confront this issue.

It cannot be understated how detrimental the devaluation of homeownership in black neighborhoods has been to these communities as a whole. That's less money for businesses, for schools, for infrastructure, for so many things that are critical to a thriving community.

In Kansas City, we are doing better than the national average, however, the average devaluation of homes in majority black neighborhoods is still 20.3%. Here are some further statistics showing the issues that arise with the devaluation of homes among the KC neighborhoods: pic.twitter.com/7PC9MLZKcx

Analysis found that metro areas with greater devaluation of black neighborhoods are more segregated & less likely to provide upward mobility for black children who grow up in them. African Americans aren't just losing $, we're missing out on same opportunities provided to others.

"Homes of similar quality in neighborhoods with similar amenities are worth 23% less in majority black neighborhoods, compared to those with very few or no black residents."

Meaning the differences in home & neighborhood quality cannot explain the differences in home value.

Researchers found that "owner-occupied homes in black neighborhoods are undervalued by $48,000 per home on average, amounting to $156 billion in cumulative losses."

That is $156 BILLION that Black Americans are being shorted strictly due to racial biases.

Yesterday, @BrookingsInst released a report on the devaluation of homeownership in black neighborhoods across the United States. It reveals the persistent institutional racism that continues to prevail in American housing markets. https://www.brookings.edu/research/devaluation-of-assets-in-black-neighborhoods/ …
